post_text: It's National School Nurse Day, and boy oh boy. Now, more than ever, we don't know what we would do without Nurse P. When the current pandemic was just starting, she was on top of (okay, WAY in front of) the research and taking action to protect our students and staff. She was side by side with our administrators advising on what was best for our school. This, on top of her daily duties of caring for our littlest kinders up through our teens who need medical attention. She steps up whenever she sees a need, like making sure our food pantry is stocked for our kids who need it. Making sure that for every field trip, that any necessary meds be taken along in case of emergency. Sending all the staff a Wellness newsletter to make us feel loved and give us tips on caring for ourselves. The list goes on and on. You really are the absolutely best we could ever dream of! Thank you thank you Marianne, we burst with appreciation for you! ‚ù§Ô∏èüë©‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è

post_text: First Grade Field Trip: What do other IB schools look like? How can we work with another classroom community? First grade students at Sage wrapped up their Communities Inquiry Unit by visiting our sister school Forge International School in Middleton. Students discovered a not-so-different learning environment 30 miles away. They took a tour of the newly built school and worked with another first grade class to tackle a STEM challenge. They enjoyed finding similarities and differences in the structures and resources at Forge, including playing in a different outdoor space and experiencing a full-service lunch kitchen. These open-minded, caring, and inclusive students say that this was the best field trip ever!

This week in Ms. Adams' 6th grade Language and Literature classes.

The students finished the novel 'Touching Spirit Bear', which tells the story of the Tlingit tribe teaching the main character about the culture of Northwest Native Americans. On Tuesday, 6th graders celebrated with a 'potlach' - a Native American gift-giving feast complete with salmon berries, venison jerky, and smoked salmon (courtesy of Ms. Adams' father). Published author, and 6th grade parent, Kim Cross, read from her story about Chinook Salmon and Ms. Adams' mother read from her published article about Chief Gray Leggings. Wednesday and Thursday were 'Red Carpet Writer Celebrations.' On Wednesday, Kim Cross returned to talk to the students about the writing process On Thursday, Kelsey Atkins, author of the 'Finding the Light' series, read to the student - and gave signed copies of her latest book to the students.
Kelly Adams

post_text: 16 Sage high schoolers left Thursday morning for Seattle to participate in a 3-day 'Model UN' conference where students from all over the northwest gather and act as delegates to international organizations. They debate a range of issues, consistent with the procedures of the UN. Our students have been working on their position papers, arguments and researching important global issues in preparation for this experience. Topics they will address include: Sustainable Agricultural Development, Food Security, and Nutrition; Protecting and Ensuring the Economic and Social Rights of Migrant Domestic Workers; and Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Rural Women and Girls. Thank you to Ms. Webster and Mr. Weeks for leading the students on this adventure! Have fun!
